body:
My idea is that the default value is `nil` and a normal behavior - it is out from the application.

And if user don't want to change it then he not use `:exit-on-close` option. He just set `:on-close` or don't use anything from it. In this case `(not (false? (:exit-on-close options)))` return `true`. Because `(:exit-on-close options) == nil`.

Otherwise user set `:exit-on-close` in `false` and `(not (false? (:exit-on-close options))) == false`

I would expect users to use "exit on close" only when they create runnable jars.

body:
This example working without `load-pixels` call. But not workink without `update-pixels` call.

This working without `load-pixels` because it called internally in https://github.com/processing-js/processing-js/blob/master/processing.js#L19049

But this behavior is not guaranteed in the future. And Processing.js docs says (carefully, a lot of traffic): https://github.com/processing-js/processing-js/blob/master/processing.js#L19116

Cite:

```
* Before accessing this array, the data must loaded with the loadPixels() function. After the array data has
* been modified, the updatePixels() function must be run to update the changes.
```

Note: 
Processing.js use `PGraphics.imageData` and `PImage.imageData` for buffering `pixels[]` array. We can't directly put our pixel values to drawing surface. We must put it to `imageData` buffer and call `updatePixels` for reloading data in drawing surface.

And (in common case) we must call `loadPixels` for reloading `imageData` buffer values from drawing surface.

Other ways to working with it is not documented and can be changed in the future I think.

body:
There is no `preload-font` in processing.js anyway, so it's not increasing gap. Quil is not a low level library so it's better if we hide these implementation details from users. If you user calls `create-font` from inside `:draw` then only the first call to preloading will have effect and all others will be cached so there won't be performance issues. 

But what happens if user tries to preload built-in font? Is it possible to know if user is using built-in font or font from  a file?

body:
Sure! This is a potentialy nitpicky bit, but boils down to whether `with-fill` should have side effects after it finishes executing.

Even when the fill is disabled, there's still a value that can be obtained from `quil.core/current-fill`. Here's an example that sets the fill to a value, disables the fill, then calls `quil.core/with-fill`.

```
(q/fill 444)
(q/no-fill)
(printf "before with-fill, current fill is %s"
        (q/current-fill))                      ;;this prints 444.
(q/with-fill 888
    (printf "inside with-fill, current fill is %s"
            (q/current-fill)))                 ;;this prints 888
(printf "after with-fill, current fill is %s"
        (q/current-fill))                      ;;what should this print?
```

I wanted calling `quil.core/with-fill` to have no side effects. That is, the final `printf` should print `444`, as though `with-fill` was never called at all.

If upon exiting `with-fill`, we only reset the fill when the fill was enabled before `with-fill`, the final `printf` would print `888`, as we haven't reset the value of the fill to what it was before.

Both the one I submitted here and the one you expected would work exactly the same for all drawing until `current-fill` is called.

### Aside

One thing that could be done is to take the overall mechanism we ended up agreeing on in this PR (that is, calling `(q/with-fill nil ...)` or `(q/with-fill false ...)` _disables_ the fill), and bringing that behavior to `quil.core/fill` and `quil.core/current-fill`. So `current-fill` would return `nil` if the fill was disabled, and `(q/fill nil)` would be identical to calling `(q/no-fill)`.

I think this would conceptually be a win, as it would lower the number of functions needed to be learned, as well as unify all fill setting functionality under `q/fill`. I'm happy to take this second part of the conversation elsewhere, as it's not strictly relevant to your question of "why does this code always set the fill?" But if `current-fill` did work this way, we could use the code you expected for `with-fill`.

Side effects make coding hard!

body:
Ah, so p5js no longer encodes color as number. 

I think `unchecked-int` was added to make sure that we convert whatever argument we got into int. For example user could pass clojure fraction or bigint and java API takes only int. Hm, actually thinking about it you probably right. When int represents color - it's not really a number, but a bit-encoding of 4 values in single number. So conversion from other type (e.g. bigint) to int doesn't make sense as it will not have correct bits anyway. 

So yes, removing unchecked-int conversions from functions that expect color sounds good. Do you want to do it in this pull request or follow up?

body:
p5 switched from `PFont` to `Object|String`. Alternative I considered was:

```clojure
(defn text-font
  (#?(:clj [^PFont font]
      :cljs [font])
   (.textFont (current-graphics) font))
  (#?(:clj [^PFont font size]
      :cljs [font size])
   (.textFont (current-graphics) font (int size))))
```
I figured this is not performance critical so I removed the type hints instead but thinking about it a bit more I suppose if call to `text-font` is inside `draw` then it's better to leave the type hints. Will switch to the version above.
